summary: Interstellar Technologies introduces Kiyoshi Kobayashi[cite: 3], Senior Fellow in Project Management[cite: 3], highlighting his experience from JAXA [cite: 4] and current role[cite: 6], and invites people to check their career page[cite: 12].

Interstellar's Director of the Board & VP of Launch Vehicle, Satoshi Nakayama, was interviewed to discuss how additive manufacturing accelerates development timelines and enables smarter designs for their launch vehicles[cite: 14, 15].

Interstellar Technologies highlights its headquarters in Taiki, Hokkaido, as central to rocket ZERO’s development, detailing processes like propellant tank welding, assembly, manufacturing, quality control, and the proximity of their launch site[cite: 17, 18, 19].

Interstellar Technologies announces the public availability of their ZERO rocket's Payload User's Guide on their website, providing technical specifications, integration process, and capabilities[cite: 21, 22].

Interstellar Technologies commemorates the May 4, 2019, MOMO F3 launch, Japan’s first privately developed rocket to reach space[cite: 23], and its role in advancing to the orbital vehicle ZERO[cite: 26].
Interstellar Technologies hosted its first Family Day at the Taiki headquarters, offering activities like crane demonstrations and launch site tours to employees' families[cite: 29].

Interstellar Technologies announces its selection for JAXA's High Accuracy Satellite Formation Flight Technology Theme [cite: 30] and held an all-company meeting discussing ZERO's development milestones and new satellite initiatives[cite: 30, 31].

Interstellar Technologies held an all-company meeting with leadership presentations on ZERO’s development, satellite initiatives, and future projects[cite: 33], including a workshop for cross-departmental connections[cite: 34].

Interstellar Technologies details Hokkaido Spaceport as the designated launch site for its ZERO orbital rocket, highlighting its wide range of launch inclinations and proximity to their factory[cite: 37, 38].
Interstellar Technologies' COO, Keiji Atsuta, is confirmed as a speaker at World Space Business Week 2025 in Paris, from September 15 to 19[cite: 40].
Interstellar Technologies shares that their capital and business alliance with Woven by Toyota has been covered, providing a link to an article about the engagement.
Interstellar Technologies highlights Aviation Week Network's coverage of their capital and business alliance with Woven by Toyota, focused on mass production of rockets[cite: 44].
Interstellar Technologies shares United Press International's coverage of Toyota's $44.4M investment and alliance with them for spaceflight[cite: 45].
Interstellar Technologies reposts CNBC coverage detailing Toyota's (via Woven by Toyota) ¥7 billion ($44.4 million) investment in Interstellar for rocket development and production[cite: 47].
Interstellar Technologies highlights TechCrunch's coverage of their capital and business alliance with Woven by Toyota and Toyota's first investment into the company[cite: 50, 52].
Interstellar Technologies shares Bloomberg News' coverage of Toyota's investment and alliance with them[cite: 53, 54].
Interstellar Technologies was mentioned during Akio Toyoda's CES 2025 press conference where he discussed Toyota Woven City and Toyota's exploration of rockets[cite: 55, 56, 58].
Interstellar Technologies highlights Reuters' coverage (in English and Japanese) of their capital and business alliance with Woven by Toyota for mass-producing rockets[cite: 62].
Interstellar Technologies shares SpaceNews' coverage of their strategic partnership and capital alliance with Woven by Toyota[cite: 63].
Interstellar Technologies highlights CNBC's coverage regarding Toyota's ¥7 billion ($44.4 million) investment and alliance with Woven by Toyota[cite: 64, 65].

Interstellar Technologies points to Woven by Toyota's press release which announced their investment and plan to leverage Toyota's expertise for mass production of Interstellar's rockets[cite: 67, 68].

Interstellar Technologies announces a strategic capital (¥7 billion Series F first close from Woven by Toyota) and business alliance with Woven by Toyota to accelerate mass production of rockets[cite: 70, 71, 73].
Interstellar Technologies hosted Minister Minoru Kiuchi (State Minister for Space Policy) in Fukushima, presenting the ZERO project, local partnerships[cite: 76], and Tohoku branch plans[cite: 77].
Interstellar Technologies features Tomoka Yasui, an engineer from their Manufacturing team[cite: 81], in their #VoiceOfOurTeam series, inviting career applications[cite: 84].
Interstellar Technologies highlights that Talk Satellite covered their announcement regarding the construction of the Tohoku branch for ZERO rocket mass production.

Interstellar Technologies announces breaking ground in Nov 2024 for its Tohoku Branch in Minamisoma, Fukushima, for ZERO mass production and advanced testing, with completion expected by Nov 2025[cite: 86, 87].

Interstellar Technologies thanks attendees of Space Tech Expo Europe, marking the end of their 2024 international exhibition season[cite: 89], and provides a link to the ZERO Payload User's Guide[cite: 90].
Interstellar Technologies promotes their ZERO Rocket embroidered flight tags available at their booth (B24, Hall 4) during Space Tech Expo Europe.
Interstellar Technologies announces their team, including Genryo Kanno and Dr. Sumio Morioka[cite: 92], is at Space Tech Expo Europe (Hall 4, Booth B24) to discuss launch services[cite: 93].

Interstellar's "Inside ZERO" series features successful tests of air cylinders for stage separation[cite: 96, 97], validating their simulation-based design approach for faster, cost-effective development[cite: 98, 99].

Interstellar Technologies announces participation in Nihonbashi Space Week 2024 (Nov 18-20, Tokyo), showcasing COSMOS engine's combustion chamber and turbopump[cite: 104], and a presentation by their Head of Communications[cite: 105].
Interstellar's "Inside ZERO" series introduces their Avionics System Simulator for comprehensive software testing using a model-based, hardware-in-the-loop approach[cite: 106, 107, 109].

Interstellar Technologies announces their participation and team presence (Genryo Kanno, Leo Koyama, Dr. Sumio Morioka, Teppei Ogawa [cite: 115]) at Space Tech Expo Europe 2024 in Bremen (Nov 19-21, Hall 4, B24 [cite: 114]).
Interstellar Technologies announces hosting their first secondee from the European Space Agency (ESA).
Interstellar Technologies wraps up their participation in the International Astronautical Congress (IAC) for the year.
Interstellar Technologies provides an update from IAC 2024, highlighting their presence at the JAXA Booth (MS-E05)[cite: 117, 118].
Interstellar Technologies' COO, Keiji Atsuta, presented updates on the ZERO rocket and company's value proposition at JAXA’s Japanese private companies showcase during IAC 2024[cite: 119].

Interstellar Technologies features Leo Koyama, Head of Mission Management[cite: 121], in their #VoiceOfOurTeam series, highlighting his role and presence at their IAC 2024 JAXA booth (MS-E05)[cite: 124].
Interstellar Technologies announces their booth (MS-E05, JAXA Booth) is live at IAC 2024, ready to discuss payload launches[cite: 125].
Interstellar Technologies shares the schedule for COO Keiji Atsuta's presentation at the IAC 2024 on Oct 15, 11:00 AM, at the JAXA Booth (MS-E05)[cite: 126, 127].
Interstellar Technologies announces the opening of a new office in Obihiro, Hokkaido in October 2024, its fifth facility, to enhance ZERO rocket manufacturing and talent acquisition[cite: 128, 129].

Interstellar Technologies announces their team's (Keiji Atsuta, Genryo Kanno, Leo Koyama, Satomi Takahashi [cite: 131]) presence at the International Astronautical Congress (IAC) 2024 in Milan (Oct 14-18, JAXA Booth MS-E05 [cite: 131]).

Interstellar Technologies announces welcoming new secondees from 7 companies, including Toyota affiliates like Toyota Auto Body and Smart Implement Inc., to leverage manufacturing expertise[cite: 135].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Olivier Finiel's announcement of starting a 6-month secondment with them in Japan as part of an EU Junior Professional Program[cite: 137].
Interstellar Technologies shares Payload's coverage of their ¥4.63 billion SBIR grant from the Japanese Government[cite: 140].
Interstellar Technologies reposts N2K | T-Minus Space Daily podcast summary, which mentions Interstellar securing a $32.5M grant from Japan's government for rocket development[cite: 143].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Payload's article about them winning a ¥4.63 billion ($32.5M) SBIR grant from the Japanese government.
Interstellar Technologies announces securing a ¥4.63 billion SBIR Phase 3 grant from MEXT (as of Sep 19, 2024) to advance development of its ZERO rocket[cite: 149, 151].
Interstellar Technologies features Yuki Yokouchi from their Ground Support Equipment team in the #VoiceOfOurTeam series, highlighting their role in building test and launch facilities[cite: 153].

Interstellar Technologies announces the successful Power Pack Test completion for the COSMOS engine's subscale turbopump (for ZERO rocket) at IHI Aerospace Aioi Test Site, marking subscale model development completion[cite: 157].

Interstellar Technologies successfully completed the Power Pack Test for its ZERO rocket's COSMOS engine subscale turbopump at IHI Aerospace Aioi Test Site[cite: 159], becoming the first Japanese venture with proprietary turbopump technology[cite: 160].
Interstellar Technologies highlights Nikkei Asia's coverage of their $21 million Series E funding round from backers including NTT[cite: 162].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Space Insider's list of top space funding rounds, which includes Interstellar's $21.5 M raise (Series E)[cite: 163].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Via Satellite's coverage of their $21 million Series E funding round[cite: 169].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Payload's article on their ¥3.1 billion ($21M) Series E funding[cite: 170], noting cumulative funding of ¥17 billion ($117M)[cite: 170].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Seraphim Space's weekly space news round-up (WC/ 05.08.24)[cite: 172], which likely featured their Series E funding.
Interstellar Technologies reposts Space Insider's newsletter which includes their ~$21 million Series E funding round among other space news[cite: 179, 182].
Interstellar Technologies announces that several media outlets (Payload, SatNews, Space Impulse, Via Satellite) have covered their Series E funding announcement[cite: 185].
Interstellar Technologies reposts Payload's article on their ¥3.1 billion ($21M) Series E funding[cite: 186], noting cumulative funding of ¥17 billion ($117M)[cite: 186].

Interstellar Technologies wraps up Small Satellite Conference (SmallSat)[cite: 187, 189], announces future IAC attendance[cite: 187, 189], and shares a link to the ZERO Payload User's Guide[cite: 188, 190].
Interstellar Technologies provides an update from Day 3 of the Small Satellite Conference (SmallSat), inviting attendees to their booth #105 in the Taggart Student Center[cite: 191].

Interstellar Technologies announces their poster session with Avionics Engineer Lui Suzuki on ZERO development progress has begun at the Small Satellite Conference (Fieldhouse)[cite: 192, 193], inviting discussion at booth #105[cite: 194].

Interstellar Technologies announces details for Avionics Engineer Lui Suzuki's poster session [cite: 195] titled "ZERO by Interstellar Technologies Inc.: Lowering the Cost of Access to Space from Japan" at SmallSat on Tuesday, August 6, 1:30pm-5:00pm in the Fieldhouse[cite: 196, 197].
Interstellar Technologies thanks SpaceNews for covering their Series E funding announcement ($21 million for rocket and satellite development) and for an interview.

Interstellar Technologies announces securing ¥3.1 billion in Series E funding from investors including SBI GROUP and NTT DOCOMO, INC.[cite: 198], bringing cumulative funding to ~¥17 billion[cite: 199].
Interstellar Technologies announces their presence at SmallSat (booth #105) [cite: 205] and reminds attendees about Avionics Engineer Lui Suzuki's poster session on ZERO development[cite: 206, 207].

Interstellar Technologies announces details for Avionics Engineer Lui Suzuki's poster session [cite: 208] titled "ZERO by Interstellar Technologies Inc.: Lowering the Cost of Access to Space from Japan" at SmallSat on Tuesday, August 6, 1:30pm-5:00pm in the Fieldhouse[cite: 209, 210, 211].

Interstellar Technologies announces the release of their official ZERO Payload User's Guide (Version 2.0, June 2024) on their website[cite: 212, 214], providing mission planning information[cite: 212].
Interstellar Technologies promotes its internship program, sharing testimonials from past interns (Yuki[cite: 215], Maya[cite: 218], Ryusei [cite: 220]) and inviting applications[cite: 224].
Interstellar Technologies features Takahiro Yoshida, Assembly group leader[cite: 225], in their #VoiceOfOurTeam series, highlighting company growth and inviting career applications[cite: 227].

Interstellar Technologies announces their team's (Keiji Atsuta, Genryo Kanno, Leo Koyama, Mika Nakagami [cite: 229]) participation at the Small Satellite Conference (SmallSat) 2024 in Utah (Aug 5-8, Booth #105 [cite: 228]).

Interstellar Technologies is featured in a Spirent Communications case study for using Spirent's PNT simulation solutions to develop and test the navigation system of their ZERO orbital launch vehicle[cite: 231, 232, 233].
Interstellar Technologies introduces a new "Book Your Launch" page on their official website for customers to inquire about launching satellites aboard their ZERO rocket[cite: 236, 237, 238].

Interstellar Technologies releases its "Interstellar Updates 2023-2024" video on YouTube[cite: 240], showcasing yearly progress across its sites (Tokyo, Fukushima, Obihiro, Taiki [cite: 242]), engine tests[cite: 243], and leadership insights[cite: 243].

Interstellar Technologies held its Business Report Meeting on July 4th, where new leadership shared updates on development and progress with supporters and journalists[cite: 245]; presentation materials available in Japanese only[cite: 246].
Interstellar Technologies congratulates on the successful third launch of the H3 rocket, linking to an article about the ALOS-4 satellite launch[cite: 247].

Interstellar Technologies hosted Vice Minister Soichiro Imaeda (MEXT) at their Hokkaido headquarters and ZERO rocket development site (HOSPO)[cite: 248], showcasing milestones and discussing public-private partnerships[cite: 249].

Interstellar Technologies was selected for the “Expanding Wireless Communication Spectrum Research Project” (FY2024) by Japan's Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, collaborating with five Japanese national universities on femto-satellite formation flying technology[cite: 250].
Interstellar Technologies announces a new management structure to strengthen R&D, business development, and fundraising for ZERO rocket development as the organization exceeds 160 members[cite: 252].
